sentences.english: He had a definite strain of snobbery in him.
sentences.chinese: 他这个人明显有一股势利小人的气味。

sentences.english: He disdained that man for snobbishness and was unwilling to talk to him.
sentences.chinese: 他鄙视那个势利小人，不愿和他说话。

sentences.english: The people I respect are straightforward ones; the ones I hate are snobs.
sentences.chinese: 我崇敬的是光明磊落的人，痛恨的是势利小人。

sentences.english: Finally, don't make the mistake of treating people according to their social standard.
sentences.chinese: 最后，不要在待人接物方面犯势利小人的错误。

sentences.english: He's a snob of the first water.
Some western snobs expressed contempt for oriental art without reason.
sentences.chinese: 西方势利小人毫无理由地看不起东方艺术。

sentences.english: He is a snob and by no means someone that can be trusted.
sentences.chinese: 他是个势利小人，绝对不可以信任。

sentences.english: We disdain a man for his snobbishness.

definition: to curry favor (idiom); playing up to those in power/social climbing
two-faced, three knives (idiom); double-cross/double dealing and back stabbing
to take advantage of one's position to bully people (idiom)/to kick people around
to think of oneself as high and pure (idiom); smug and self-righteous/holier-than-thou
to cling to the powerful and rich (idiom); social climbing
lit. see the wind and set the helm (idiom); fig. to act pragmatically/to be flexible and take advantage of the situation
lit. a vile character flourishes (idiom)/fig. an inferior person gets into a position of power, becoming conceited and arrogant
to see profit and forget morality (idiom); to act from mercenary considerations/to sell one's soul for gain
to smooth whiskers and pat a horse's bottom (idiom); to use flatter to get what one wants/to toady/boot-licking
lit. honeyed words, a sword in the belly (idiom); fig. hypocritical and murderous
